text.p: Paramount Pictures is going ahead with a sequel to the Tom Cruise blockbuster, "Mission: Impossible" and hopes to release it in the summer of 1998, Daily Variety reported in its Friday edition.
The big-screen version of the spy TV series has grossed $175 million domestically since opening May 22, and $338 million overseas so far.
It's the biggest success for Viacom Inc-owned Paramount since 1994's "Forrest Gump". However, many critics complained its plot was incomprehensible.
Cruise will reprise his roles as star and co-producer, and will soon meet Academy Award-winning screenwriter William Goldman, who will write the script, the report said.
It said "Mission: Impossible" director Brian De Palma would have first crack at the sequel, though no deals have been made yet.

Goldman, whose Oscars were for "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid" and "All the President's Men", earlier this summer criticised some of the season's blockbusters. However, he singled out "Mission: Impossible" as an especially entertaining movie, Daily Variety said.
